Type.Name: HttpCapabilitiesBase
Type.ThreadSafetyStatement: Gtk# is thread aware, but not thread safe; See the <link location="node:gtk-sharp/programming/threads">Gtk# Thread Programming</link> for details.

remarks.para: is the base class from which the class is derived. offers a large number of read-only properties that provide type-safe access to a browser's capabilities dictionary. You can access the class through the property that is exposed by the ASP.NET property.

summary.para: Provides access to detailed information about the capabilities of the client's browser.
Creates a new instance of the class.
Gets a value indicating whether the browser supports ActiveX controls.
Returns the collection of available control adapters.
Used internally to add an entry to the internal collection of browsers for which capabilities are recognized.

Docs.param: The name of the browser to add.

summary.para: Gets a value indicating whether the client is an America Online (AOL) browser.
Gets a value indicating whether the browser supports playing background sounds using the <bgsounds> HTML element.

remarks.para: Beta version browsers can exhibit unpredictable behavior.

summary.para: Gets a value indicating whether the browser is a beta version.
Gets the browser string (if any) that was sent by the browser in the User-Agent request header.
Gets an of the browsers in the dictionary.

remarks.para: The property applies only to WML-compatible mobile devices. If true, the adapter can output multiple forms from the same page as cards of a single deck, where possible.

summary.para: Gets a value indicating whether the browser supports decks that contain multiple forms, such as separate cards.

remarks.para: The property applies only to WML-compatible mobile devices.

summary.para: Gets a value indicating whether the browser device is capable of initiating a voice call.

remarks.para: The property applies only to WML-compatible mobile devices.

summary.para: Gets a value indicating whether the browser supports page content following WML <select> or <input> elements.
Gets a value indicating whether the browser supports empty HTML <select> elements.

remarks.para: The property applies only to WML-compatible mobile devices.

summary.para: Gets a value indicating whether the browser supports WML INPUT and SELECT elements together on the same card.

remarks.para: The property applies only to WML-compatible mobile devices.
If false, onpick values are displayed as hyperlinks and value attributes require a <do> element for postback.

summary.para: Gets a value indicating whether the browser supports WML <option> elements that specify both onpick and value attributes.

remarks.para: The property applies only to WML-compatible mobile devices.
If false, WML <onevent> and <prev> elements that coexist within the same WML card will not be properly rendered.

summary.para: Gets a value indicating whether the browser supports WML <onevent> and <prev> elements that coexist within the same WML card.

remarks.para: The property applies only to WML-compatible mobile-device browsers.
If false, postback cards will not be properly rendered by the browser.

summary.para: Gets a value indicating whether the browser supports WML cards for postback.

remarks.para: The property applies only to WML-compatible mobile devices.
If false, HTML <setvar> elements with a value attribute of 0 will not display correctly.

summary.para: Gets a value indicating whether the browser supports WML <setvar> elements with a value attribute of 0.
Gets a value indicating whether the browser supports sending e-mail by using the HTML <mailto> element for displaying electronic addresses.
Used internally to get the defined capabilities of the browser.
Gets a value indicating whether the browser supports Channel Definition Format (CDF) for webcasting.

remarks.para: The property is supported only when the browser is Internet Explorer version 5.0 and later.
If the .NET Framework is not installed on the client, the value of the version elements returned is 0, 0,-1,-1.
If more than one version of the .NET Framework is installed on the client, the property returns the latest version.

summary.para: Gets the version of the .NET Framework that is installed on the client.

remarks.para: The property indicates whether the browser application supports cookies. If the user has disabled cookies in their application, the property will not be affected.

summary.para: Gets a value indicating whether the browser supports cookies.
Gets a value indicating whether the browser is a search engine Web crawler.
Creates a new instance of the to be used.

returns.para: A new instance of the to be used.

remarks.para: The property primarily represents the number of soft keys that are available on a WML-compatible mobile device.

Web Forms pages for mobile devices can contain a object and more than one control. The allows you to choose which of the controls should be assigned to a soft key on devices that have multiple soft keys.

summary.para: Returns the maximum number of Submit buttons that are allowed for a form.
Used internally to disable use of an optimized cache key.
Gets the version number of ECMAScript that the browser supports.
Gets a value indicating whether the browser supports HTML frames.
Gets the major version number of the wireless gateway used to access the server, if known.
Gets the minor version number of the wireless gateway used to access the server, if known.
Gets the version of the wireless gateway used to access the server, if known.

remarks.para: The method is supported only when the browser is Internet Explorer version 5.0 or later. If the common language runtime is not installed on the client, the property returns an array containing a single object with the values 0, 0,-1,-1.

summary.para: Returns all versions of the .NET Framework common language runtime that are installed on the client.

MemberSignature.Value: public static System.Web.Configuration.HttpCapabilitiesBase GetConfigCapabilities (string configKey, System.Web.HttpRequest request);

summary.para: Used internally to return an instance of representing the browser that generated the specified .

returns.para: An instance of representing the browser that generated the specified .

Docs.param: The name of the configuration section that configures browser capabilities.
The generated by the browser for which to return capabilities and which is usually the current .

remarks.para: If false, a link control might be necessary when a Back button is not available.

summary.para: Gets a value indicating whether the browser has a dedicated Back button.
Gets a value indicating whether the scrollbar of an HTML <select multiple> element with an align attribute value of right is obscured upon rendering.
Gets or sets the fully qualified class name of the to use.
Gets the internal identifier of the browser as specified in the browser definition file.
Used internally to initialize an internal set of values.

remarks.para: Possible return values include:

summary.para: Returns the type of input supported by browser.

remarks.para: The method also returns true if the client browser definition inherits from the specified browser.

summary.para: Gets a value indicating whether the client browser is the same as the specified browser.

returns.para: true if the client browser is the same as the specified browser; otherwise, false. The default is false.

summary.para: Gets a value indicating whether the browser has a color display.
Gets a value indicating whether the browser is a recognized mobile device.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual string this[string key] { get; }

summary.para: Gets a value indicating whether the browser supports Java.

remarks.para: If the browser supports JavaScript but scripting is disabled through a security setting, the property will return true but script will not execute on the browser.

summary.para: Gets a value indicating whether the browser supports JavaScript.
Gets the JScript version that the browser supports.
Gets the major (integer) version number of the browser.
Gets the maximum length in characters for the href attribute of an HTML <a> (anchor) element.

remarks.para: Processing by an intermediate gateway can change the number of bytes that reach the browser. ASP.NET does not enforce this limit on page size.
is primarily useful when working with mobile-client browsers.

summary.para: Gets the maximum length of the page, in bytes, which the browser can display.

remarks.para: The property applies only to WML-compatible mobile devices.

summary.para: Returns the maximum length of the text that a soft-key label can display.
Gets the minor (that is, decimal) version number of the browser.
Gets the minor (decimal) version number of the browser as a string.
Returns the name of the manufacturer of a mobile device, if known.
Gets the model name of a mobile device, if known.
Gets the version of Microsoft HTML (MSHTML) Document Object Model (DOM) that the browser supports.

remarks.para: The property applies only to WML-compatible mobile devices.
Soft keys are special keys that the application can usually map to custom tasks. Soft-key text is displayed on the screen in the lower-left and lower-right corners.

summary.para: Returns the number of soft keys on a mobile device.

remarks.para: Some of the possible values for the property are as follows:

item.para: WinNT (all other versions of Windows NT)

summary.para: Gets the name of the platform that the client uses, if it is known.
Returns the MIME type of the type of image content typically preferred by the browser.
Returns the MIME type of the type of content typically preferred by the browser.
Gets the general name for the type of content that the browser prefers.
Gets the request encoding preferred by the browser.
Gets the response encoding preferred by the browser.

remarks.para: The property applies only to WML-compatible mobile devices.
If true, content following <select> or <input> elements will automatically be placed on a new line.

summary.para: Gets a value indicating whether the browser renders a line break before <select> or <input> elements.

remarks.para: If true, content following list-item elements will automatically be placed on a new line.

summary.para: Gets a value indicating whether the browser renders a line break after list-item elements.

remarks.para: The property applies only to WML-compatible mobile devices.
If true, content following a stand-alone HTML <a> (anchor) element will automatically be placed on a new line.

summary.para: Gets a value indicating whether the browser renders a line break after a stand-alone HTML <a> (anchor) element.

remarks.para: The property applies only to WML-compatible mobile devices.
If true, content following an HTML <input> element will automatically be placed on a new line.

summary.para: Gets a value indicating whether the browser renders a line break after an HTML <input> element.

remarks.para: The property applies only to WML-compatible mobile devices.

summary.para: Gets a value indicating whether the mobile-device browser renders a WML do-based form accept construct as an inline button rather than as a soft key.

remarks.para: The property applies only to WML-compatible mobile devices.

summary.para: Gets a value indicating whether the browser renders WML <select> elements as menu cards, rather than as a combo box.

remarks.para: Intended for internal use only. Some browsers require a meta-tag similar to the following for the browser to render properly.

summary.para: Used internally to produce a meta-tag required by some browsers.

remarks.para: Some browsers do not recognize colons in element attribute values. If true, a different character will be substituted on rendering and returned in postback data.

summary.para: Gets a value indicating whether the browser requires colons in element attribute values to be substituted with a different character.

remarks.para: If true, server-control adapters insert the following tag into the HTML <head> element of a Web page:
In this example, is the value returned by the property, and charset is the character encoding used.

summary.para: Gets a value indicating whether the browser requires an HTML <meta> element for which the content-type attribute is specified.
Gets a value indicating whether the browser requires control state to be maintained in sessions.
Gets a value indicating whether the browser requires a double-byte character set.

remarks.para: If true, the browser does not properly render HTTP error messages. To correct this, server control adapters generate a custom error page for the browser.

summary.para: Gets a value indicating whether the browser requires nonstandard error messages.

remarks.para:
If true, server-control adapters insert an additional
element immediately following the tag in a Web page.

summary.para:
Gets a value indicating whether the browser requires the first element in the body of a Web page to be an HTML
element.

remarks.para:
If true, the browser will not correctly render pages containing the HTML
element.

summary.para:
Gets a value indicating whether the browser does not support HTML
elements to format line breaks.

remarks.para: If true, server control adapters generate minimal output to reduce the size of the resulting page.

block.para: The property returns true for i-mode–compatible browsers.

summary.para: Gets a value indicating whether the browser requires pages to contain a size-optimized form of markup language tags.

remarks.para: The property applies only to browsers for which the property is true.

summary.para: Gets a value indicating whether the browser supports phone dialing based on plain text, or whether it requires special markup.

remarks.para: HTTP is a stateless protocol, and VIEWSTATE is one mechanism used to persist client changes across multiple requests. Each control on a Web page contains a property, which represents the accumulation of any changes made by the client. In a Web Forms page, these changes are encoded in postback data as the value of an HTML <input> element with a type attribute of hidden. For example:

If true, non-alphabetic characters in the VIEWSTATE value will not be sent correctly by the browser, nor by an intermediate gateway. To correct this, server-control adapters replace non-alphabetic characters in the VIEWSTATE value with ones that do not require encoding in HTTP requests.

summary.para: Gets a value indicating whether the browser requires VIEWSTATE values to be specially encoded.

remarks.para: A self-referring HTML <form> element is one for which the action attribute specifies its own URL. If true, self-referring forms do not return the correct results. This is due to caching by either the browser or an intermediate gateway. To correct this, server control adapters append a default query string (__ufps=) onto the form-action URL values of self-referring forms.

summary.para: Gets a value indicating whether the browser requires unique form-action URLs.
Gets a value indicating whether the browser requires unique name attribute values of multiple HTML <input type="checkbox"> elements.
Gets a value indicating whether the browser requires unique name attribute values of multiple HTML <input> elements.
Gets a value indicating whether postback data sent by the browser will be UrlEncoded.
Returns the depth of the display, in bits per pixel.

remarks.para: The returned value can be derived from the assumed character size and actual screen pixel size. The algorithm for determining the height uses a combination of the default font sizes (from a .config file), browser-specific sizes (again, from a .config file), and explicit headers sent by the browser. Some browsers might rely on internal default values, which only approximate the actual height.

summary.para: Returns the approximate height of the display, in character lines.

remarks.para: The returned value can be derived from the assumed character size and actual screen pixel size. The algorithm for determining the width uses a combination of the default font sizes (from a .config file), device-specific sizes (again, from a .config file), and explicit headers sent by the devices. These values are not necessarily exact (especially for variable-width fonts, these values are approximate). Some devices might rely on internal default values, which only approximate the actual width.

summary.para: Returns the approximate width of the display, in characters.

remarks.para: The returned value can be derived from the assumed character size and character height. The algorithm for determining the pixel height uses a combination of the default font sizes (from a .config file), device-specific sizes (again, from a .config file), and explicit headers sent by the devices. These values are not necessarily exact. Some devices might rely on internal default values, which only approximate the actual height.

summary.para: Returns the approximate height of the display, in pixels.

remarks.para: The returned value can be derived from the assumed character size and character width. The algorithm for determining the pixel width uses a combination of the default font sizes (from a .config file), device-specific sizes (again, from a .config file), and explicit headers sent by the devices. These values are not necessarily exact (especially for variable-width fonts, these values are approximate). Some devices might rely on internal default values, which only approximate the actual width.

summary.para: Returns the approximate width of the display, in pixels.

remarks.para: The accesskey attribute extends control of forms and links on a Web page to mobile and accessible platforms by assigning a soft key or other controller on the device to interact with HTML <a> (anchor) and <input> elements.

summary.para: Gets a value indicating whether the browser supports the ACCESSKEY attribute of HTML <a> (anchor) and <input> elements.
Gets a value indicating whether the browser supports the bgcolor attribute of the HTML <body> element.
Gets a value indicating whether the browser supports HTML <b> elements to format bold text.

remarks.para: The cache-control value for the http-equiv attribute of HTML <meta> elements allows control over client caching of downloaded content, which includes Web pages. The following HTML fragment shows an example:
If true, the inclusion of this tag in the <head> element of a Web page should force the browser to reload content from the server.
If false, server control adapters append a default query string (__ufps=) onto link URL values that do not already have one. This forces the browser to reload content from the server.
The property also applies to the equivalent HTTP header form:

summary.para: Gets a value indicating whether the browser supports the cache-control value for the http-equiv attribute of HTML <meta> elements.
Gets a value indicating whether the browser supports callback scripts.
Gets a value indicating whether the browser supports Cascading Style Sheets (CSS).

remarks.para: HTML <div> elements are used to group multiple HTML elements so that CSS styles can be applied to them as a whole. The align attribute sets the horizontal alignment of a <div> group on a Web page.

summary.para: Gets a value indicating whether the browser supports the align attribute of HTML <div> elements.

remarks.para: HTML <div> elements are used to group multiple HTML elements so that CSS styles can be applied to them as a whole. The nowrap attribute specifies that the elements contained in the <div> group should remain adjacent to each other without wrapping to a new line.

summary.para: Gets a value indicating whether the browser supports the nowrap attribute of HTML <div> elements.
Gets a value indicating whether the browser supports empty (null) strings in cookie values.
Gets a value indicating whether the browser supports the color attribute of HTML <font> elements.
Gets a value indicating whether the browser supports the name attribute of HTML <font> elements.
Gets a value indicating whether the browser supports the size attribute of HTML <font> elements.
Gets a value indicating whether the browser supports using a custom image in place of a standard form Submit button.

remarks.para: The property applies only to i-mode–compatible devices.
Set i-Phone–specific picture symbols for i-mode–compatible browsers by using the property.

summary.para: Gets a value indicating whether the browser supports i-mode symbols.

remarks.para: The property applies only to i-mode–compatible devices.
The istyle attribute is used for setting the input style of a text-input field on i-mode–compatible browsers.

summary.para: Gets a value indicating whether the browser supports the istyle attribute of HTML <input> elements.

remarks.para: The property applies only to i-mode–compatible devices.
The MODE attribute is used for setting the input mode of a text input field on i-mode–compatible browsers.

summary.para: Gets a value indicating whether the browser supports the mode attribute of HTML <input> elements.
Gets a value indicating whether the browser supports HTML <i> elements to format italic text.

remarks.para: The property applies only to J-Phone–compatible mobile devices.

J-Phone is a markup language specification, based on HTML, for J-Phone–compatible browsers. If true, the browser supports additional attributes for HTML <a> (anchor) and <select> elements. The additional attributes supported are as follows:

summary.para: Gets a value indicating whether the browser supports J-Phone multimedia attributes.

remarks.para: The property applies only to J-Phone–compatible mobile devices.
Set J-Phone–specific picture symbols for J-Phone–compatible browsers by using the property.

summary.para: Gets a value indicating whether the browser supports J-Phone–specific picture symbols.

remarks.para: If false, query string parameters are sent, in postback data, as HTML <input> elements with the type attributes set to hidden.

summary.para: Gets a value indicating whether the browser supports a query string in the action attribute value of HTML <form> elements.

remarks.para: With UP.Browser 4.1 or UP.Browser 3.2, the method behaves as if the value of the property of the object is false, unless the property in the section of Web.config has been explicitly set to true.

In ASP.NET 1.1, the options for this setting were true or false, but with ASP.NET 2.0, the choices are expanded, and is now the default setting. If your Web application has the cookieless attribute of the <sessionState> section in the Web.config file set to a Boolean value, should work as expected for these browsers.

summary.para: Gets a value indicating whether the browser supports cookies on redirection.
Gets a value indicating whether the browser supports the multiple attribute of HTML <select> elements.

remarks.para: If false, the value of the checked attribute of HTML <input type=checkbox> elements is omitted from postback data.

summary.para: Gets a value indicating whether the clearing of a checked HTML <input type=checkbox> element is reflected in postback data.
Gets a value indicating whether the browser supports receiving XML over HTTP.
Used internally to compare filters.

returns.para: 1 if is a parent of ; -1 if is a parent of ; 0 if there is no parent-child relationship between and .

summary.para: Used internally to evaluate a filter.

returns.para: true if the filter was successfully evaluated; otherwise, false.

summary.para: Gets a value indicating whether the browser supports HTML <table> elements.
Used internally to get the type of the object that is used to write tags for the browser.
Gets the name and major (integer) version number of the browser.
Used internally to get a value indicating whether to use an optimized cache key.
Gets a value indicating whether the browser supports Visual Basic Scripting edition (VBScript).

remarks.para: The property returns a string. In some scenarios, the property might contain letter characters, as in the case of a browser or client device that is a beta version such as "7.0b." To correctly get the version as a data type that can be used in a numeric comparison, concatenate the and property values.

summary.para: Gets the full version number (integer and decimal) of the browser as a string.
Gets the version of the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) XML Document Object Model (DOM) that the browser supports.
Gets a value indicating whether the client is a Win16-based computer.
Gets a value indicating whether the client is a Win32-based computer.
